Award.AwardTitle: CCLI:TYPE1:Enhancing the ECE 101 Curriculum Through Student Diversity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Engineering - Other (59)
This project is transforming a course to capitalize on the diversity of the students enrolled in the course and to incorporate course content of immediate interest to students. This is being done by developing a new classroom pedagogy, called diversity harnessing, in which the direct interests of the student population are folded back into course materials through lecture topics, homework exercises and exam problems. Diversity harnessing is making extensive use of active and collaborating learning. The course, ECE 101: Exploring Digital Information Technology, is an engineering course for non-engineering majors that strives to prepare students for a meaningful role in an increasingly technological society. The goals of this project are to 1) better engage the students in the course topics, 2) quickly integrate diverse student-driven subject matter back into the course, and 3) empower the students to more effectively apply new skills to their lives and careers. The project includes rigorous formative and summative evaluation plans with both qualitative and quantitative components coordinated by an independent evaluator.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since 2003, we have regularly offered a course ECE 101, Exploring Digital Information Technologies, to students who are not engineering majors. For these students, ECE 101 fulfills a campus general education requirement. In the open-ended final project for ECE 101, students apply what they have learned to design hardware or software in the laboratory, to create a device or system of their choice. Because students have varying backgrounds and academic majors, they can individualize the final project assignment according to their personal or professional interests. With funding from NSF, we developed a method to incorporate students' diverse interests into the lecture part of the course, a method that we call "diversity harnessing." Each week, questionnaires gather students' ideas about potential applications for course topics, related to their interests. Students' ideas are quickly integrated into the lectures, homework exercises, and exam problems. We hypothesized that diversity harnessing would improve student engagement in ECE 101, because the real-world applications would increase student motivation.

To assess the outcomes of ECE 101, particularly the effectiveness of diversity harnessing, we collected two kinds of data. First, we administered the Student Course Engagement Questionnaire (SCEQ) of Handelsman et al. to measure students' levels of engagement, multiple times during the semester, before and after the implementation of diversity harnessing. Second, we interviewed students who had completed ECE 101 to assess the long-term impact of the course, in comparison with other general education courses that students have taken. From the SCEQ data, we consistently found no significant differences. From the interviews, we found that the students' relationships with the instructor and teaching assistants promoted their persistence through challenging course material and laboratory assignments. Students considered JavaScript and HTML the most important knowledge that they gained. Our most intriguing finding was students' paradoxical interpretations of (partial) failures of their ECE 101 final projects as successful outcomes, because the final project improved their skills and their confidence in the development and debugging of hardware and software. In other words, these non-engineering students valued the outcomes of the experience of the design process, without discouragement about the failure of the actual product to meet the specifications that they had chosen.

Two graduate students [Larson, Revelo Alonso] and four undergraduate students [Davis, He, Le, Vazquez] participated in this project. These students included four women in engineering, one African American, and two Latina/o Americans.
